intro: Acacia montis-usti, commonly known as the mountain acacia, is a shrub native to the arid regions of northern Africa and the Middle East. It is characterized by its dense, thorny foliage and small, yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are often modified into spines, a common adaptation to reduce water loss in dry environments. Its roots are deep and extensive, allowing it to access groundwater in nutrient-poor soils. Acacia montis-usti plays an important ecological role by providing shelter and food for various desert wildlife species.

It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky outcrops and dry savanna habitats. This species is well adapted to withstand high temperatures and low precipitation, making it a common sight in these regions. It plays an important ecological role by providing shelter and food for various wildlife species. Its distribution is largely restricted to the specific climatic conditions of its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia montis-usti was mainly introduced to areas with well-drained soils and a semi-arid climate, typically found in regions with moderate temperatures and low precipitation. It thrives in open landscapes such as grasslands and rocky outcrops where it can receive ample sunlight. This plant is often used for soil stabilization due to its extensive root system and ability to tolerate drought conditions.
